description: This course focuses on American fiction of the late 19th and early 20th centuries that reflects changing attitudes towards gender roles; sexual identity and behavior; and marriage, motherhood, and divorce. Students read works of fiction by Henry James, Kate Chopin, Charlotte Perkins Gilman, Edith Wharton, and others, and analyze these texts in the context of the cultural and literary controversies they generated.
name: Top: Sex, Madness & Marriage
notes: Open to juniors and seniors who have completed English 185 and at least two
level-II English courses or by permission of the instructor.
This course has class-year limits. Only open to juniors and seniors.

Open to juniors and seniors who have completed English 185 and at least two level-II English courses or by permission of the instructor. This course has class-year limits.

revisions.description: Students explore specific periods in American literature and examine the relationship between literary texts and movements and their particular cultural, political, and historical contexts. Each offering of this course examines a different literary era and emphasizes specific literary and historical issues. Click on course title in the class and lab for more information about the course for that term. Counts toward American studies major. Prerequisites: ENGL 185 plus at least two English courses at level II, or permission of the instructor.
revisions.prerequisites: Prerequisites: ENGL 185 plus at least two English courses at level II, or permission of the instructor.

title: Advanced Studies in Literary Eras: American
